forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
We had today too much time on our hands at work and did some random time killing activities.  
One was piting our newer computers against some older ones, in deathmatches. ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif)  

One of the strangest things was, that USB-Boot-Speed was absolutely identical across all machines.  
The tested boards were from different manufacturers, even the chipset and CPU and BIOS manufacturers differed.  
However the 188MB boot-image did load on all machines in 14,9 +- 0,05 seconds, which means roughly 12,5MB/s. The stick itself tested with 24MB continuous read speed.   
Also used some other sticks with lower(17MB/s) or higher(31,7MB/s) read speeds. The loading time for the image stayed absolutely identical.  

Has anyone else come across this phenomenon or can attest to a higher USB-Boot-Speed?  

btw. It was an XP based PE image.  

![:smiling9:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/smiling9.gif)

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: Have you have added a USB driver of some sort so it boots from USB?? Maybe that is the limiting factor?

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
The image get's loaded by BIOS routines, only after the image is loaded into ram, the kernel takes over and one can use drivers.  

The curious thing is the value 12,5MB/s. I don't recognize it as any known limit.   
Also assuming that PIO mode is used, to load the image, the actual speed of PIO mode depends highly on the CPU. Which should cause a way broader spectrum on speeds.
